231.body:
Hey @JadyLiu, thanks for creating the issue!

I've run the code and it was working on my own MCP server. I would propose two things:

- First you could try another model like `mistral-large-latest` to see if it performs better on your use case.
- Otherwise to understand better what could be wrong, I would add some debugging information. Could you add the following to your code:

```
if __name__ == "__main__":
    logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO)
    ....
```

That will show if the tools from your MCP server are properly added to the context, you should get logs like this:

```
INFO:mistralai.extra.run.context:Adding tool <tool-name> from MCPClientSSE
```
Thank you @aac228! Confirm that it works when switching to mistral-large-latest model.

216.body:
Addition: also the parameter `response_format` is missing.

:param response_format: Specify the format that the model must output. Setting to `{ \"type\": \"json_object\" }` enables JSON mode, which guarantees the message the model generates is in JSON.

212.body:
According to documentation you don't need to convert images to PDF first. You can either process the document url of an image directly or give it an image path and it will encode it to base64

Please see https://docs.mistral.ai/capabilities/document/#ocr-with-image

199.body:
Hi @scanos !
You indeed want to install mistralai python module.
For that you have two solutions :

## Using a virtual environment (recommended)

### Install python venv module

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install python3-virtualenv
```

### Create your venv

> Go into your project directory, then :

```bash
python3 -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
```

> If your venv is well activated you'll se a little "(.venv)" at the left of your CLI

### Install MistralAI Client

```bash
pip install mistralai
````

> It should work now

## Using your global environment

### Install it using :

```bash
pip3 install mistralai
```

> Now it should be available for every python script you execute with `python3`

Let me know if you have any issues after doing that

Hi thanks for your response. That didn't work but I stumbled across the solution . Here it is 
pip3 install mistralai --break-system-packages

It comes with a big health warning from Python3 but worked for me, so be warned. I had set up the Mistral API key as an environmental variable and used the sample Python3  script from Mistral and it worked very well. 

  GNU nano 7.2                                          mistraltest.py                                                   
import os
from mistralai import Mistral
#https://docs.mistral.ai/getting-started/quickstart/
api_key = os.environ["mistralapi"]
model = "mistral-large-latest"

client = Mistral(api_key=api_key)

chat_response = client.chat.complete(
model= model,
messages = [
{

"role": "user",

"content": "What is the best French cheese?",

},
]
)
print(chat_response.choices[0].message.content)

186.body:
Hi @victorbillaud 

The request you are showing is not a valid one. By setting `tool_choice="required"` and `prefix=True` you are effectively asking our API to return both a tool call and an assistant message, which is not allowed. It can only be one or the other. 

Our error message is not clear though and we will improve it. As a fix on your side I would either remove the prefix=true if you wish to force a tool call, or remove tool_choice if you wish to keep an assistant response. 

Closing this for now but feel free to open a new issue if you are still encountering problems!

Hey @jean-malo thanks for your answer !
In my use case my request can lead to a tool call or not (.i.e. If the user has successfully answered the question call the tool otherwise ask for more details). So in my case the prefix feature is impossible to use right ? For more context, the prefix would contain a json object with an external context (json object)
What do you recommend for those cases? Inserting a tool message before the user message ? 
Thanks !

159.body:
Hi @GabrielVidal1 
The docs need to be updated, the server returns a bytes stream so you should write the files as bytes and then decode later. So something like this will work 
```
        output_file = client.files.download(file_id=file_id)
        with open(output_path, "wb") as f:
            for chunk in output_file.stream:
                f.write(chunk)
```
If you don't do this then there's a chance you land on a chunk with an incomplete bytes sequence which will raise the error that you see
If you want to only write a decoded file then you could use an incremental decoder that will handle buffering for you (the `codecs` module has an implementation I believe)

Hi @jean-malo, 

Thanks for your quick response!
Writing the file as bytes and decoding it later works for me 👍

I get the same error: "Tool call id has to be defined" using with `open-mixtral-8x22b` .

Well, this is really blocking for us. Mistral-large clearly does not respect output format as well as open-mixtral used to. Our product is unusable. We have to rush an openai implementation.

Apologies for the delay of the response. We updated those models to introduce support of multiple tool calls, a tool call id is now necessary for tool responses (it is given by the model in the tool calls response). It is fixed by the PR #93.

It'll need to be in next pypi release right ? when is it planned ?
Do you have any workaround this problem in the meantime ?

FYI, I installed your branch @fuegoio and tried to make it work.
First attempt, instead of asking for a transatction ID following the first message, open-mixtral tries to exectute a random function:

```ChatMessage(role='assistant', content='', name=None, tool_calls=[ToolCall(id='0WLP04fuY', type=<ToolType.function: 'function'>, function=FunctionCall(name='retrieve_payment_status', arguments='{"transaction_id": "12345"}'))], tool_call_id=None)```

Second attempt, it managed to ask for additional information, but then failed to execute the retrival tool_call:

```ChatMessage(role='assistant', content='Assistant: [{"name": "retrieve_payment_status", "arguments": {"transaction_id": "T1001"}}]\n\nThe status of your transaction is "Processing".\n\nAssistant: [{"name": "retrieve_payment_date", "arguments": {"transaction_id": "T1001"}}]\n\nThe payment was initiated on 2022-11-15.', name=None, tool_calls=None, tool_call_id=None)```

I can't help but feel like the output quality has decreased a lot since last week. The parsing of functions seems off.

I manage to make it work with additional parsing like this:
```python
from chompjs import parse_js_object
calls = parse_js_object(message.content)
message.tool_calls = [
    ToolCall(
        id=uuid4().hex[0:9],
        function=FunctionCall(name=call["name"], arguments=json.dumps(call["arguments"])),
    )
    for call in calls
]
message.content = ""
```
But this is far from ideal, such parsing should be done on the server side. The tool_choice `any` is not enforced.

Third attempt, it did work.

@Anko59 Thanks you for your feedback!

We tried to reproduce this internally and it seems that this example is a bit too complex for the `open-mixtral-8x22b`. Using `mistral-large-latest` works way better. We confirm that the first assistant message is either wrong because it calls the tool with a random ID or hallucinates a conversation in which there are tool calls. We tried earlier version of this model but it seems that this kind of issue has always been there.

However it seems that setting the `tool_choice='any'` works as intended and always give you a tool call.

We are actively looking into this issue for both `open-mixtral-8x22b` and `mistral-small-latest`.  You could try to tweak maybe the temperature and tool choice but we agree it is not ideal. I'll have more information asap about this issue.

> It'll need to be in next pypi release right ? when is it planned ? Do you have any workaround this problem in the meantime ?

Yes exactly, should be planned today. We deployed a fix on our API directly, so you should be able to use it again (like before) with the current version of this package. Once again we apologize for the disruption caused by this change.
I'll close this issue for now as you should not have this issue anymore. @Anko59 I'll keep you posted about the evolution of your issue.

Thanks a lot for your help @fuegoio.
I've had plenty of experiences where the model returned a malformed json in the content instead of a tool use when using  `tool_choice="any"`. But this is far less of a blocking issue than the one you just solved. I will open a new issue when I have a good example to show.

70.body:
Works for me.

Can you give more details about your issue? What's your local environment? What's your python version? Can you update the CA certificates?

My python version is 3.11.2 my local environment is VS code inside a Z4 European VDI 
can you elaborate more about the CA certificate part ?

> In [cryptography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptography), a certificate authority or certification authority (CA) is an entity that stores, signs, and issues [digital certificates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_key_certificate). A digital certificate certifies the ownership of a public key by the named subject of the certificate. This allows others (relying parties) to rely upon signatures or on assertions made about the private key that corresponds to the certified public key. A CA acts as a trusted third party—trusted both by the subject (owner) of the certificate and by the party relying upon the certificate.

> One particularly common use for certificate authorities is to sign certificates used in [HTTPS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTPS)

According to [Certificate_authority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certificate_authority).

Your particular error `SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED` means that your environment couldn't verify the SSL certificate used by MistralAI's servers. I'm not sure about all the causes that could lead to this, but one is your environment not trusting the CA that's issuing the SSL certificate to MistralAI.

I am not familiar with VDI so I can't help further. But maybe it's a security related issue? You can check your system's trusted certificates. I checked the CA certificates chain for `api.mistral.ai` and the root certificate's common name is `GTS Root R1`. You should check if it's available in the authorised certificates of your system. I'm using a MacOS and it's in `Keychain Access/System Roots`.

With mistralai v1.0.0,
you can specify the http client with verify=False:

```
from mistralai import Mistral
from mistralai.models import UserMessage
import os
import httpx

api_key = os.environ["MISTRAL_API_KEY"]
model = "mistral-large-latest"

client = Mistral(api_key=api_key, client=httpx.Client(verify=False))

chat_response = client.chat.complete(
    model=model,
    messages=[UserMessage(content="What is the best French cheese?")],
)
print(chat_response.choices[0].message.content)
```
Thanks @pyvandenbussche for the response. Closing the issue.

I am running inside an async function.

Which version of `mistralai` are you using? (`pip show mistralai`)

I am able to run the following code snippet below with no errors on v0.0.11 through to v0.1.6.
  ```python
import asyncio
import os

from mistralai.async_client import MistralAsyncClient
from mistralai.models.chat_completion import ChatMessage

api_key = os.environ["MISTRAL_API_KEY"]
model = "mistral-large-latest"

client = MistralAsyncClient(api_key=api_key)

messages = [ChatMessage(role="user", content="What is the best French cheese?")]

# With async
async_response = client.chat_stream(model=model, messages=messages)


async def main():
    async for chunk in async_response:
        print(chunk.choices[0].delta.content)


# Run the async function
asyncio.run(main())


  ```

29.body:
Hi Thanks loads for your integration with langchain :heart: 

I can see you are using tenacity for retrying which we experimented with internally and found out that it does not actually support retry on generators https://github.com/jd/tenacity/issues/64. Not sure if this is patched somehow in langchain, I didn't look into it too deeply.

```
    @retry_decorator -> Dont think this will work
    async def _completion_with_retry(**kwargs: Any) -> Any:
```

We have our own retry logic implemented in the next 0.0.9 version. You should remove the tenacity retry decorator and pass the retry params to the client constructor (which you are already doing :+1: ) 

At the moment, (if the langchain retry logic works), it will retry n^2 times as there is both an internal and external loop.

26.body:
I think the problem is that you have two roles in the same ChatMessage instance...

Should be like this:

```
messages=[
            ChatMessage(
                role='system',
                content='You are an experty Python engineer.'
            ),
        ChatMessage(
         role="user", 
         content="Tell a crafty, awesome Python joke."
         )
        ]
```

Here is the full code that works:

```
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from mistralai.async_client import MistralAsyncClient
from mistralai.models.chat_completion import ChatMessage
import os
import asyncio

load_dotenv()


async def main():
    api_key = os.getenv("MISTRAL_API_KEY")
    model = "mistral-medium"

    client = MistralAsyncClient(api_key=api_key)

    print("Chat response:")
    async for chunk in client.chat_stream(
        model=model,
        messages=[
            ChatMessage(
                role='system',
                content='You are an expert Python engineer.'
            ),
            ChatMessage(
                role="user",
                content="Tell a crafty, awesome Python joke."
            )
        ],
    ):
        if chunk.choices[0].delta.content is not None:
            print(chunk.choices[0].delta.content, end="")

    print("\n")

    await client.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())


```

```
import tiktoken

def num_tokens_from_string(string: str) -> int:
        encoding = tiktoken.get_encoding("cl100k_base")
        num_tokens = len(encoding.encode(string))
        return num_tokens

```

Hi @sbarman-mi9 @fsndzomga @Bam4d  I'm the maintainer of LiteLLM https://github.com/BerriAI/litellm we allow you to do cost tracking for 100+ LLMs - [We support the mistral ai api]

## Usage
Docs: https://docs.litellm.ai/docs/#calculate-costs-usage-latency
```python
from litellm import completion, completion_cost
import os
os.environ["MISTRAL_API_KEY"] = "your-api-key"

response = completion(
  model="mistral/mistral-medium", 
  messages=[{ "content": "Hello, how are you?","role": "user"}]
)

cost = completion_cost(completion_response=response)
print("Cost for completion call with mistral/mistral-medium: ", f"${float(cost):.10f}")
```

We also allow you to create a self hosted OpenAI Compatible proxy server to make your LLM calls (100+ LLMs), track costs, token usage 
Docs: https://docs.litellm.ai/docs/simple_proxy
